Ask HN: How do you think LLMs will affect society medium/long term?
text:
I know obviously there is a ton of discussion about GPT-4 in the main announcement post, and while I'm blown away by a lot of these capabilities, I honestly don't understand how our capitalist system will survive this, long term. I'm not a Luddite, but it's pretty easy for me to see how this will get rid of the need for tons of jobs. People always love to say "technology replacing people has been happening since the beginning of time", but the change here (at least to me) is that the rate by which AI can fill jobs will (or has?) hit a tipping point where it will be faster than new jobs will pop up.

How do other people feel about this? I've discounted tons of hype cycles in the past (crypto/Blockchain, Metaverse, etc.), even in cases where I was wrong (e.g. the importance of mobile), but this feels at least as consequential as the Internet to me.

Tell HN: Fiverr Autoblocked Me as a Seller
text:
Hello all; I am writing to add my own little horror story regarding getting crushed by automated systems to HN's graveyard of dreams :)

I was introduced to fiverr by a friend a few days ago, after I expressed interest to teach undergraduate and graduate mathematics, problem solving, and coach students for competitions (Olympiads, Putnam) online.

So I made an account (which bizarrely involved giving Fiverr write access to my github account), followed the steps to write a gig, and even drew a little collage of my previous work (images for problems I designed, papers I wrote etc.).

The moment I clicked 'publish' for my gig, I received a rejection notice and two minutes later my account was closed for selling. Initially I was confused, but then I suspected that my title "I teach mathematics, problem solving, and the basics of research" was mistaken as a service offering to solve students' homework (I assume that is the issue).

So I emailed customer support:

--------------------------------- Hello; I tried posting a gig to teach mathematics, problem solving and the basics of research(undergraduate and graduate). My gig was instantly rejected and seller eligibility removed; I presume because the automated system thought I was offering to solve their homework problems. How can this be amended or reversed, if at all?

Regards, Ioannis Konstantoulas -------------------------

A few hours later I got the human (?) response:

------------------------ Hi there, Thank you for reaching out to us about this issue. We understand you tried to open a Seller profile on Fiverr, and received our response explaining your request wasn't approved Unfortunately, this decision can’t be changed. Your seller profile wasn’t approved, but you are welcome to continue using Fiverr as a buyer. If there is anything else we can help you with, please let us know. All the best, ------------------------

So... that is that then. To make this a little less depressing, can HN people recommend a service where I can offer one-on-one mathematics help at the undergraduate and graduate level?

I was going to create custom sessions for each student's needs, create tailored problem sets to target specific weaknesses, solve the problems together with the student to give guided experience, and employ all the mastery learning techniques I have practiced over the years. I'd love to get recommendations, but please do not recommend sites that will reject the above by bot and then confirm the rejection by human!

Oh, and how do I make sure Fiverr stops having write access to my github account?

Ask HN: What is the future of Mass Metadata Collection for training LLMs?
text:
The current crop of LLMs have been trained on three decades of the internet and not on private comms (AFAIK). This makes them weak in real-life applications that don't involve computer-assisted tasks.

What measures do you foresee "AI" corps taking to increase the amount of data they have available for training?

Ask HN: Large language model business use cases?
text:
First I want to preface this by saying that I see value in large language models and transformer technology, I've personally gotten value out of ChatGPT using it as an assistant in product and software development.

However I can't help shake the feeling that we're being sold a bit of snake oil when it comes to the APIs and business use cases. In the demos I've watched in events from OpenAI, Cohere, Scale etc I haven't seen any major compelling business use cases. Even today's GPT-4 demo, where they showed it understanding tax code and answering tax questions, what is the use case? If I'm developing tax software do I bake this into my product to answer questions? Why can't someone just use ChatGPT or any other bot built on top of it to accomplish the same thing? Why are they using my bot that uses the same API as everyone else?

Has anyone found and solved really compelling business use cases with LLMs?

title: Ask HN: What is the best stack for real-time collaboration web apps?
text:
I'm scoping different languages, and their frameworks, for their ability to build web applications with real-time collaboration (AKA multiplayer mode, a la Google Docs / Replit).

For context, I will use the stack to build a Leetcode-style sport coding application that enables pair programming in 2-on-2 ranked matches.

I am familiar with Python so Django seems a natural fit. However, other forums have reported Django's limited async capabilities. I also looked into Yjs, but would prefer to avoid JS-land as I will be working solo. Multiple sources have recommended Elixir with Phoenix— learning a FP language appeals to me and LiveView seems a nice way to avoid JS.

I would like to get the HN community's take. What tech stack would you use for this greenfield project?
